item.title: Amazon Product Recommender
item.description: This project uses Amazon product review and meta data up to 2018 to create recommender systems: one approach was write a commandline program that would return personalized recommendations for a user profile, which involved thorough evaluation of models using both collaborative and content-based filtering methods. The github repo shows the model evaluation in detail. I went with the SVD algorithm (a collaborative filtering method) for the commandline approach, and then made a Flask web app with pre-computed sets of products which are similar to a specific product (content-based method).

item.title: Factors associated with online purchasing behavior
item.description: This project models purchasing behavior of an e-commerce website in terms of analytics such as number of pages viewed, type of web page visited and duration (e.g. product related or administrative pages), and other features such as ‘bounce rates’, ‘exit rates’, etc. associated with a binary target variable (1 = purchase; 0 = no purchase). The overarching goal was to tune a model to the purchasing behavior and derive feature importance - i.

item.title: The X-Files: Insights from data
item.description: Here I scraped and cleaned data such as IMDB ratings, writer, director, number of viewers, episode transcripts, category (‘Mythology’ or not) for every episode of The X-Files, and did a deep dive to understand how these features correlate with episode rating. I used statistical testing methods such as Welch’s T-test and the Mann-Whitney U test to probe the influence of writers, directors and characters on episode rating, and modelled the ratings progression through the series with a number of methods to understand where the show peaks and which episodes are rated more highly.
